articles.headline: Plug-In Cars Pose Riddle for E.P.A.
articles.snippet: Just two months before the Chevrolet Volt and Nissan Leaf enter showrooms, how the E.P.A. will measure the cars’ fuel economy remains a question.
articles.abstract: Just two months before the Chevrolet Volt and Nissan Leaf enter showrooms, how the E.P.A. will measure the cars’ fuel economy remains a question.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  About two months before two new plug-in cars go on sale in the United States, the federal government is struggling with how to rate the fuel economy of mass-market plug-in vehicles.
articles.byline: By Nick Bunkley and Bill Vlasic

articles.headline: Lending Is Up, but Demand Is Lacking
articles.snippet: Bank lending to companies is starting to rise, but until demand increases, many companies have no need to borrow money to expand or hire.
articles.abstract: Bank lending to companies is starting to rise, but until demand increases, many companies have no need to borrow money to expand or hire.
articles.lead_paragraph: Corporate lending by banks is rising. Finally.

articles.headline: Push to End Job Barriers Rattles Greece and Economy
articles.snippet: Interest groups oppose breaking down the barriers to entry in lucrative niches, but experts say they cost the economy billions a year.
articles.abstract: Interest groups oppose breaking down the barriers to entry in lucrative niches, but experts say they cost the economy billions a year.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Antonios Avgerinos, 59, a retired army pharmacist, always wanted his own pharmacy here. And why not? Greek law ensures that pharmacists get a 35 percent profit on all drugs sold, even over-the-counter medications.

articles.headline: Boehner’s Path to Power Began in Small-Town Ohio
articles.snippet: Everything about John A. Boehner stems from a small town that seems untouched since his childhood.
articles.abstract: Everything about John A. Boehner stems from a small town that seems untouched since his childhood.
articles.lead_paragraph: READING, Ohio  John A. Boehner, the House Republican leader, laments that the America he grew up in has been “snuffed out” by Democrats. Yet Mr. Boehner’s hometown seems virtually untouched by the decades that have passed since he lugged kegs of beer around his father’s bar, tossed a Friday night football and frightened a driving instructor by burning rubber in a GTO.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Steinhauer and Carl Hulse

articles.headline: Mortgage Mess May Cost Big Banks Billions
articles.snippet: Bank stocks fell as analysts said the political furor over foreclosures could translate into billions in costs.
articles.abstract: Bank stocks fell as analysts said the political furor over foreclosures could translate into billions in costs.
articles.lead_paragraph: One billion dollars? Six billion? Ten billion? More?

articles.headline: Tea Party Set to Win Enough Races for Wide Influence
articles.snippet: The movement stands a good chance of establishing a sizable caucus to push its agenda in the House and the Senate, according to a New York Times analysis.
articles.abstract: The movement stands a good chance of establishing a sizable caucus to push its agenda in the House and the Senate, according to a New York Times analysis.
articles.lead_paragraph: Enough Tea Party-supported candidates are running strongly in competitive and Republican-leaning Congressional races that the movement stands a good chance of establishing a sizable caucus to push its agenda in the House and the Senate, according to a New York Times analysis.

articles.headline: U.S. Uses Attacks to Nudge Taliban Toward a Deal
articles.snippet: The United States appears to be pursuing a dual-track strategy in Afghanistan of force and talks.
articles.abstract: The United States appears to be pursuing a dual-track strategy in Afghanistan of force and talks.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  Airstrikes on Taliban insurgents have risen sharply here over the past four months, the latest piece in what appears to be a coordinated effort by American commanders to bleed the insurgency and pressure its leaders to negotiate an end to the war.

articles.headline: From a Maine House, a National Foreclosure Freeze
articles.snippet: A volunteer’s work helped put one house at the center of a furor over foreclosures.
articles.abstract: A volunteer’s work helped put one house at the center of a furor over foreclosures.
articles.lead_paragraph: DENMARK, Me. — The house that set off the national furor over faulty foreclosures is blue-gray and weathered. The porch is piled with furniture and knickknacks awaiting the next yard sale. In the driveway is a busted pickup truck. No one who lives there is going anywhere anytime soon.

articles.headline: Taking a Vote on Union Construction
articles.snippet: Voters in some communities have approved measures that bar city officials from favoring unions in construction contracts.
articles.abstract: Voters in some communities have approved measures that bar city officials from favoring unions in construction contracts.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO  California’s go-go construction industry came crashing to earth when the housing bubble burst. Ever since, union leaders and nonunion contractors have fought hammer and tongs for a bigger share of the shrunken business, much of which is public sector construction.

articles.headline: Settlement May Be Near in Countrywide Case
articles.snippet: Three former leaders of the mortgage lender are said to be discussing a deal in the S.E.C.’s securities fraud lawsuit.
articles.abstract: Three former leaders of the mortgage lender are said to be discussing a deal in the S.E.C.’s securities fraud lawsuit.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Talks over settling at least part of the securities fraud lawsuit filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission against three former executives of the Countrywide Financial Corporation have intensified, two people involved with the case said Thursday.

articles.headline: Bernanke Weighs Risks of New Action
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, indicated that the bank would take steps to try to fight unemployment and low inflation.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, indicated that the bank would take steps to try to fight unemployment and low inflation.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON  The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, went further on Friday in outlining the risks the central bank was prepared to take by pumping more money into the flagging recovery.

articles.headline: U.S. to Investigate China’s Clean Energy Aid
articles.snippet: The Obama administration pledged to investigate Beijing’s subsidies to its clean-energy industries while delaying a politically volatile report on the Chinese currency.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration pledged to investigate Beijing’s subsidies to its clean-energy industries while delaying a politically volatile report on the Chinese currency.
articles.lead_paragraph: The economic tension between the United States and China escalated on Friday, as the Obama administration pledged to investigate Beijing’s subsidies to its growing clean energy industries while delaying a politically volatile report on the Chinese currency.
articles.byline: By Sewell Chan and Keith Bradsher
